Description: Gold ear-ring (one of a pair): five hollow, triangular tubes soldered together, with a longer centre tube to fit through the lobe. At the beginning of this extension, a small five-petaled flower has been soldered on, so that it would have rested against the lobe when the ring was worn.
Curator's comments: For the suggestion that such rings, introduced in the 17th dynasty, could be worn with two on each ear, see Eaton-Krauss in Egypt’s Golden Age (exhibition catalogue, Boston, 1982): 229. Pair with 1917,1015.3 Bibliography: 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 270-271 No 84; 'Temples and Tombs' [exhibition catalogue] (American Federation of Arts, 2006), 85, cat no. 43. Pair with 1917,1015.4 Bibliography: 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 270-271 No 84; 'Temples and Tombs' [exhibition catalogue] (American Federation of Arts, 2006), 85, cat no. 43.
Bibliographic references: Russmann 2001 / Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum (86)
Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.208-209)
Museum of Fine Arts Boston 1982 / Egypt's Golden Age: The Art of Living in the New Kingdom 1558-1085 BC (294)
